byline.original: By JULIE TURKEWITZ and ERIC LICHTBLAU
byline.contributor: Julie Turkewitz reported from Denver, and Eric Lichtblau from Washington.

lead_paragraph: Investigators said questions had been raised as to why F.B.I. agents did not disclose that they had fired shots when LaVoy Finicum, an occupier at the Malheur National Wildlife Refuge, was confronted.

headline.print_headline: Shooting of Occupier Is Called Justified; F.B.I. Faces Scrutiny
headline.main: Police Shooting of Oregon Occupier Declared Justified, but F.B.I. Faces Inquiry

snippet: Investigators said questions had been raised as to why F.B.I. agents did not disclose that they had fired shots when LaVoy Finicum, an occupier at the Malheur National Wildlife Refuge, was confronted.
abstract: Investigators find no culpability on part of Oregon state officers in deadly shooting of LaVoy Finicum, one of activists who occupied Malheur National Wildlife Refuge; federal officials begin probe into actions of Federal Bureau of Investigation agents for not disclosing that they also fired shots, none of which struck Finicum, during confrontation.
